steps.title: Purchase whole, untreated mung beans.
steps.content: Purchase whole, untreated mung beans. Do not use beans packaged in gardening packets, which have probably been chemically treated. Check the label to make sure you’re purchasing whole and untreated beans which are made for sprouting and eating. [1] X Research source Find mung beans at health food stores or online catalogues like Sproutpeople (sproutpeople.org) and Sproutman (sproutman.com).

steps.title: Measure out your desired amount of mung beans.
steps.content: Measure out your desired amount of mung beans. Consider the size of the bowl or jar you plan to soak them in—the beans should fill about ¼ of the container. Mung beans get much bigger once they sprout, so be careful not to use too much. [2] X Research source The yield for sprouting mung beans is about 2 to 1, meaning if you use 1 pound of seeds you’ll end up with 2 pounds of sprouts. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse your mung beans using a colander or strainer.
steps.content: Rinse your mung beans using a colander or strainer. Run clean water over the beans until it runs clear. They may be dusty, since the majority of mung beans are grown in China and are often left to dry on gravel roads. [4] X Research source This will help protect you from anything which might have been in the soil, like metals and toxins. It will also wash away things like mites that may have made their way into the dried beans.

steps.title: Place the beans in a clear, wide-mouth jar.
steps.content: Place the beans in a clear, wide-mouth jar. Mason canning jars are a great option, but you can also reuse jars that held peanut butter or pasta sauce, for instance. The beans should fill up about a quarter of your container. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Submerge the beans in water and cover the jar with a mesh lid.
steps.content: Submerge the beans in water and cover the jar with a mesh lid. Fill the jar partway with cool water, roughly 2-3 times the volume of the beans. Then, cover your jar with some type of breathable lid. [6] X Research source For a homemade option, you can use a piece of cheesecloth secured with rubber band. You could also punch holes into an existing metal or glass lid. You could also purchase a specialized sprouting jar, which is sold with a pre-made strainer lid. If you don’t have cheesecloth or a mesh lid, you can also soak your beans uncovered in a bowl or jar.

steps.title: Soak the beans for 8-12 hours until they swell up.
steps.content: Soak the beans for 8-12 hours until they swell up. How long they have to soak will depend on the beans. Generally, larger beans will require a longer soak. You can place the jar on the countertop or in a cabinet—just make sure it’s not positioned in direct sunlight. [7] X Research source The beans should be soaking at room temperature, not in the fridge.

steps.title: Drain and rinse the beans through the mesh lid.
steps.content: Drain and rinse the beans through the mesh lid. Drain away the excess water through the lid of your jar by flipping it over in the sink. Then, rinse the swollen beans with fresh water and drain it again. [8] X Research source If you don’t have a mesh lid or cheesecloth, you can also hold a strainer against the opening of your jar to drain the water.

steps.title: Put the jar in a cool, dark place for 12 hours.
steps.content: Put the jar in a cool, dark place for 12 hours. Find a place that gets little to no sunlight where the beans will not be disturbed. Place the jar upside down and at an angle on a dish rack or cooling rack so the moisture can continue to be released. [9] X Research source Although the beans should not be exposed to direct sunlight, there’s no need for the storage location to be completely dark. A shadowy corner of your countertop would work well.

steps.title: Repeat this process every 12 hours for 2-5 days.
steps.content: Repeat this process every 12 hours for 2-5 days. Rinse and drain the beans through the mesh lid approximately every 12 hours (or twice a day). Return them to their dark storage spot after each rinse session. [10] X Research source The beans should continue to grow in size and sprout thin white tails.

steps.title: Give the sprouts a rinse once they’ve reached your desired length.
steps.content: Give the sprouts a rinse once they’ve reached your desired length. Pour the sprouted beans into a colander and give them one last rinse before draining them thoroughly. Generally, mung beans taste good when they’re about 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) long—but it’s mostly a matter of personal preference. [11] X Research source The green shells may have started to come off the white bean sprouts at this point. You can remove some of these empty shells from the mix with your hands if you like. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Spread the sprouted beans across a baking sheet lined in paper towels.
steps.content: Spread the sprouted beans across a baking sheet lined in paper towels. Cover a baking sheet with two layers of dry paper towels, then pour the rinsed and drained beans on top. Spread them out in a thin layer with your hand and press gently to absorb any excess water. Once you’ve patted them dry, they are ready to be stored. [13] X Research source Pick out any unsprouted beans and throw them away. To dry the beans even more thoroughly, cover them with another paper towel and press gently.

steps.title: Place the sprouts into a bowl and store in the fridge for up to 2 weeks.
steps.content: Place the sprouts into a bowl and store in the fridge for up to 2 weeks. Line the bowl with paper towels, then use your hands to transfer handfuls of sprouts into the container. Plan to eat the sprouts within 2 weeks. [14] X Research source Mung bean sprouts are a great base for a chilled salad, or a classic addition to a stir-fry.
